values.description:
The [nightly build for yakkety is failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo8-debbuilder/698/consoleFull#-17067195856ea37b8d-a6d4-40ae-8431-d90c018842af) due to a bad check of ffmpeg version. Two fixes here:

 * Check against version 3.1 (57, 40, 101). Use `LIBVFORMAT_VERSION_INT` since the support for codecpar is part of the `libavformat.h` header.
 * Fix warnings on `av_free_packet` by using `av_packet_unref`.
values.title: Fix gazebo8 build in yakkety: avcodec proper version check

summary.raw:
The [nightly build for yakkety is failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo8-debbuilder/698/consoleFull#-17067195856ea37b8d-a6d4-40ae-8431-d90c018842af) due to a bad check of ffmpeg version. Two fixes here:

 * Check against version 3.1 (57, 40, 101). Use `LIBVFORMAT_VERSION_INT` since the support for codecpar is part of the `libavformat.h` header.
 * Fix warnings on `av_free_packet` by using `av_packet_unref`.
summary.html:
The nightly build for yakkety is failing due to a bad check of ffmpeg version. Two fixes here:

  • Check against version 3.1 (57, 40, 101). Use LIBVFORMAT_VERSION_INT since the support for codecpar is part of the libavformat.h header.
  • Fix warnings on av_free_packet by using av_packet_unref.

values.description:
While I was running tests to compare the states of two worlds I noticed two member variables in physics::Link which are never really used anywhere: *linearAccel* and *angularAccel*.

To explain how I found this and to reproduce the state comparison failure:

- get the LinkState of one Link, e.g. ``LinkState s(yourLink);``
- set another Link to the same state, i.e. ``otherLink->SetState(s); ``
- get the new state of the second link, i.e. ``LinkState s2(otherLink);`` - both links should now have the same state.
- compare the states ``s1`` and ``s2`` see that accelerations are *not* the same.

Reason why they are not: The LinkState is created from the states of Link::WorldLinearVel(), Link::WorldLinearAccel() etc., so from the states in *world frame* (see LinkState.cc constructor). However when the link is set to a specific state in Link::SetState, it uses Link::SetLinearAccel and Link::SetAngularAccel, which simply write the values in the member variables *linearAccel* and *angularAccel*. However... *those values are never read anywhere again*, in the whole code base. This is maybe a remnant of old times?

I removed all functions related to setting accelerations and compiled/tested, which confirmed that the functions were actually never called from anywhere. Another reason for the removal is that setting accelerations explicitly from the Link interface doesn't make sense, this is something the physics engine determines. When an acceleration is to be applied to a body, a *force* should be used instead - this then determines acceleration in the next update step, and the resulting acceleration may (though in the ideal world should not) differ between engines.
I am wondering whether this is also why setting the acceleration is not supported by any of the physics engine's Link subclasses (and which is why Link's SetLinear/AngularAccel is not virtual).

One remaining issue with the accelerations is that setting the state of a Link from LinkState will now just skip the acceleration value. But this never was working anyway: as it was, it was just setting the unused member variables; acceleration was always determined by the physics engines.

**Additional suggestion**

I would also like to suggest the following trivial changes to the interface, though I haven't included it in this PR yet:
Would it maybe be better to rename functions

* Link::SetLinearVel
* Link::SetAngularVel
* Link::SetForce and
* Link::SetTorque

to the following: 

* Link::SetWorldLinearVel
* Link::SetWorldAngularVel
* Link::SetWorldForce and
* Link::SetWorldTorque.

This way they match with the getter names (e.g. Link::WorldLinearVel()) which further avoids confusion. From looking at the physics engine's Link implementations, that's what the methods are intended to do anyway: set the world velocity, not the relative velocity.
values.title: Remove two members in Link that are never really used and are confusing

summary.raw:
While I was running tests to compare the states of two worlds I noticed two member variables in physics::Link which are never really used anywhere: *linearAccel* and *angularAccel*.

To explain how I found this and to reproduce the state comparison failure:

- get the LinkState of one Link, e.g. ``LinkState s(yourLink);``
- set another Link to the same state, i.e. ``otherLink->SetState(s); ``
- get the new state of the second link, i.e. ``LinkState s2(otherLink);`` - both links should now have the same state.
- compare the states ``s1`` and ``s2`` see that accelerations are *not* the same.

Reason why they are not: The LinkState is created from the states of Link::WorldLinearVel(), Link::WorldLinearAccel() etc., so from the states in *world frame* (see LinkState.cc constructor). However when the link is set to a specific state in Link::SetState, it uses Link::SetLinearAccel and Link::SetAngularAccel, which simply write the values in the member variables *linearAccel* and *angularAccel*. However... *those values are never read anywhere again*, in the whole code base. This is maybe a remnant of old times?

I removed all functions related to setting accelerations and compiled/tested, which confirmed that the functions were actually never called from anywhere. Another reason for the removal is that setting accelerations explicitly from the Link interface doesn't make sense, this is something the physics engine determines. When an acceleration is to be applied to a body, a *force* should be used instead - this then determines acceleration in the next update step, and the resulting acceleration may (though in the ideal world should not) differ between engines.
I am wondering whether this is also why setting the acceleration is not supported by any of the physics engine's Link subclasses (and which is why Link's SetLinear/AngularAccel is not virtual).

One remaining issue with the accelerations is that setting the state of a Link from LinkState will now just skip the acceleration value. But this never was working anyway: as it was, it was just setting the unused member variables; acceleration was always determined by the physics engines.

**Additional suggestion**

I would also like to suggest the following trivial changes to the interface, though I haven't included it in this PR yet:
Would it maybe be better to rename functions

* Link::SetLinearVel
* Link::SetAngularVel
* Link::SetForce and
* Link::SetTorque

to the following: 

* Link::SetWorldLinearVel
* Link::SetWorldAngularVel
* Link::SetWorldForce and
* Link::SetWorldTorque.

This way they match with the getter names (e.g. Link::WorldLinearVel()) which further avoids confusion. From looking at the physics engine's Link implementations, that's what the methods are intended to do anyway: set the world velocity, not the relative velocity.
summary.html:
While I was running tests to compare the states of two worlds I noticed two member variables in physics::Link which are never really used anywhere: linearAccel and angularAccel.

To explain how I found this and to reproduce the state comparison failure:

  • get the LinkState of one Link, e.g. LinkState s(yourLink);
  • set another Link to the same state, i.e. otherLink->SetState(s);
  • get the new state of the second link, i.e. LinkState s2(otherLink); - both links should now have the same state.
  • compare the states s1 and s2 see that accelerations are not the same.

Reason why they are not: The LinkState is created from the states of Link::WorldLinearVel(), Link::WorldLinearAccel() etc., so from the states in world frame (see LinkState.cc constructor). However when the link is set to a specific state in Link::SetState, it uses Link::SetLinearAccel and Link::SetAngularAccel, which simply write the values in the member variables linearAccel and angularAccel. However... those values are never read anywhere again, in the whole code base. This is maybe a remnant of old times?

I removed all functions related to setting accelerations and compiled/tested, which confirmed that the functions were actually never called from anywhere. Another reason for the removal is that setting accelerations explicitly from the Link interface doesn't make sense, this is something the physics engine determines. When an acceleration is to be applied to a body, a force should be used instead - this then determines acceleration in the next update step, and the resulting acceleration may (though in the ideal world should not) differ between engines. I am wondering whether this is also why setting the acceleration is not supported by any of the physics engine's Link subclasses (and which is why Link's SetLinear/AngularAccel is not virtual).

One remaining issue with the accelerations is that setting the state of a Link from LinkState will now just skip the acceleration value. But this never was working anyway: as it was, it was just setting the unused member variables; acceleration was always determined by the physics engines.

Additional suggestion

I would also like to suggest the following trivial changes to the interface, though I haven't included it in this PR yet: Would it maybe be better to rename functions

  • Link::SetLinearVel
  • Link::SetAngularVel
  • Link::SetForce and
  • Link::SetTorque

to the following:

  • Link::SetWorldLinearVel
  • Link::SetWorldAngularVel
  • Link::SetWorldForce and
  • Link::SetWorldTorque.

This way they match with the getter names (e.g. Link::WorldLinearVel()) which further avoids confusion. From looking at the physics engine's Link implementations, that's what the methods are intended to do anyway: set the world velocity, not the relative velocity.

values.description:
One of the steps in the tutorial runs gazebo using background execution. If you fail to shutdown it
after the next step, gazebo crash with an exception without more information. This PR will display:

```
ERROR: Unable to start server[bind: Address already in use]. There is probably another Gazebo process running.
```

Much better. Easier for revewing: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2618/proper-exception-handling-for-animated-box/diff?w=1
values.title: Proper exception handling for animated box example

summary.raw:
One of the steps in the tutorial runs gazebo using background execution. If you fail to shutdown it
after the next step, gazebo crash with an exception without more information. This PR will display:

```
ERROR: Unable to start server[bind: Address already in use]. There is probably another Gazebo process running.
```

Much better. Easier for revewing: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2618/proper-exception-handling-for-animated-box/diff?w=1
summary.html:
One of the steps in the tutorial runs gazebo using background execution. If you fail to shutdown it after the next step, gazebo crash with an exception without more information. This PR will display:

ERROR: Unable to start server[bind: Address already in use]. There is probably another Gazebo process running.

Much better. Easier for revewing: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2618/proper-exception-handling-for-animated-box/diff?w=1

values.description:
Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

I updated my local checkout yesterday and compiled Gazebo 8 prior to release to get a preview, but gzclient promptly segfaulted.  This was hard to debug as the segfault occurred before `main()`.  After a lot of head-scratching and recompiling in debug mode, I finally realized it was linking to both Qt4 and Qt5 on my Xenial machine.

It turned out the reason it did so was because it automatically selected `libqwt.so.6.1.2`, since I had failed to notice the need for installing package `libqwt-qt5-dev`.  Installing this and re-running cmake (with cleared cache !) fixed the problem.  However, if Gazebo is switching unconditionally to Qt5 for this release, I'd recommend changing `SearchForStuff.cmake` to only use qwt-qt5.

Perhaps this is only Ubuntu-related, and the name `qwt` is used on other platforms.  In that case it would be nice to detect somehow if the selected library is Qt4 or Qt5, because the condition where the program simply crashes before `main()` is very hard to understand.  It occurs for any program that links both libQt5Gui.so and libQtGui.so, which happens in gzclient if libqwt is selected instead of libqwt-qt5.
values.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

After a lot of head-scratching and recompiling in debug mode, I finally realized it was linking to both Qt4 and Qt5 on my Xenial machine.

It turned out the reason it did so was because it automatically selected `libqwt.so.6.1.2`, since I had failed to notice the need for installing package `libqwt-qt5-dev`.  Installing this and re-running cmake (with cleared cache !) fixed the problem.  However, if Gazebo is switching unconditionally to Qt5 for this release, I'd recommend changing `SearchForStuff.cmake` to only use qwt-qt5.

Perhaps this is only Ubuntu-related, and the name `qwt` is used on other platforms.  In that case it would be nice to detect somehow if the selected library is Qt4 or Qt5, because the condition where the program simply crashes before `main()` is very hard to understand.  It occurs for any program that links both libQt5Gui.so and libQtGui.so, which happens in gzclient if libqwt is selected instead of libqwt-qt5.

Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

I updated my local checkout yesterday and compiled Gazebo 8 prior to release to get a preview, but gzclient promptly segfaulted. This was hard to debug as the segfault occurred before main(). After a lot of head-scratching and recompiling in debug mode, I finally realized it was linking to both Qt4 and Qt5 on my Xenial machine.

It turned out the reason it did so was because it automatically selected libqwt.so.6.1.2, since I had failed to notice the need for installing package libqwt-qt5-dev. Installing this and re-running cmake (with cleared cache !) fixed the problem. However, if Gazebo is switching unconditionally to Qt5 for this release, I'd recommend changing SearchForStuff.cmake to only use qwt-qt5.

Perhaps this is only Ubuntu-related, and the name qwt is used on other platforms. In that case it would be nice to detect somehow if the selected library is Qt4 or Qt5, because the condition where the program simply crashes before main() is very hard to understand. It occurs for any program that links both libQt5Gui.so and libQtGui.so, which happens in gzclient if libqwt is selected instead of libqwt-qt5.

values.description:
On the screen of my MacBook Pro running Ubuntu Xenial, the GL render fills only the top-left quarter of the screen.  This patch seems to fix it.
I'll note that devicePixelRatio() returns 2.0, but it seems this needs to be taken into account for OGRE's Render Window size.
values.title: Fix HIDPI issue with GLWidget window size.

summary.raw:
On the screen of my MacBook Pro running Ubuntu Xenial, the GL render fills only the top-left quarter of the screen.  This patch seems to fix it.
I'll note that devicePixelRatio() returns 2.0, but it seems this needs to be taken into account for OGRE's Render Window size.
summary.html: On the screen of my MacBook Pro running Ubuntu Xenial, the GL render fills only the top-left quarter of the screen. This patch seems to fix it. I'll note that devicePixelRatio() returns 2.0, but it seems this needs to be taken into account for OGRE's Render Window size.

values.description:
This is a continuation of pull request #2619, sorry still getting used to bitbucket.. I made a branch to continue the PR since I had made the change on "default", and it seems I can't change the origin branch of the PR so I had to create a new one.

Ok, this commit reverts the removal of "qwt" and replaces it with an explicit check of the dependencies of QWT_LIBRARY.  This means that it will use tools like "ldd" on Linux and "otool" on Mac (through CMake's GET_PREREQUISITES macro) and check them for the string Qt5Gui.  If it's not found an error is issued.  If the variable QWT_DEPENDENCIES is empty, i.e. GET_PREREQUESITES did not work properly, the check is skipped.  Tested only on Xenial, but I think this is more robust than checking the library name on certain operating systems.

* Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

    Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

* Explicitly check dependencies of qwt for Qt5
values.title: Prefer qwt qt5 linux

summary.raw:
This is a continuation of pull request #2619, sorry still getting used to bitbucket.. I made a branch to continue the PR since I had made the change on "default", and it seems I can't change the origin branch of the PR so I had to create a new one.

Ok, this commit reverts the removal of "qwt" and replaces it with an explicit check of the dependencies of QWT_LIBRARY.  This means that it will use tools like "ldd" on Linux and "otool" on Mac (through CMake's GET_PREREQUISITES macro) and check them for the string Qt5Gui.  If it's not found an error is issued.  If the variable QWT_DEPENDENCIES is empty, i.e. GET_PREREQUESITES did not work properly, the check is skipped.  Tested only on Xenial, but I think this is more robust than checking the library name on certain operating systems.

* Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

    Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

* Explicitly check dependencies of qwt for Qt5
summary.html:
This is a continuation of pull request #2619, sorry still getting used to bitbucket.. I made a branch to continue the PR since I had made the change on "default", and it seems I can't change the origin branch of the PR so I had to create a new one.

Ok, this commit reverts the removal of "qwt" and replaces it with an explicit check of the dependencies of QWT_LIBRARY. This means that it will use tools like "ldd" on Linux and "otool" on Mac (through CMake's GET_PREREQUISITES macro) and check them for the string Qt5Gui. If it's not found an error is issued. If the variable QWT_DEPENDENCIES is empty, i.e. GET_PREREQUESITES did not work properly, the check is skipped. Tested only on Xenial, but I think this is more robust than checking the library name on certain operating systems.

  • Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

    Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

  • Explicitly check dependencies of qwt for Qt5

values.description:
This adds integration of a Siconos-based Physics engine to Gazebo.  Note that it currently depends on the git 'master' branch of Siconos.  Once Siconos 4.1.0 is released, I will work on stable and 'master' versions.  Siconos is not yet available through Debian/Ubuntu, however a daily PPA is [available](https://code.launchpad.net/~siconos/+archive/ubuntu/siconos-daily) and a stable Debian package is currently in development.

This currently only supports a couple of primitives and joint types, and parameters are hard-coded.  Very much work in progress.  It may be better to leave it in a branch for now, but I make this PR to make the work public.

Siconos is a general modeling and simulation library for non-smooth dynamical systems, of which mechanical rigid body systems are a subset.  More information on Siconos can be found at http://siconos.gforge.inria.fr/

* Add physics engine "siconos", with a skeleton PhysicsEngine instance.

    No joints implemented, parameters are hard-coded, many TODO items, but
    basic bouncing ball works.

* Add SiconosBoxShape.

* Add rudimentary "add force" mechanism to SiconosLink.

* Add a bit of friction to the default NSLaw.

* Vector conversions for SiconosVector and ignition.

* Use a SiconosContactor for each shape.

* Enable the GeneralMechanical solver.

* Implement SiconosHingeJoint.

* Implement SiconosSliderJoint.

* Change gazebo8_siconos_integration to siconos_integration
values.title: Siconos integration

summary.raw:

Once Siconos 4.1.0 is released, I will work on stable and 'master' versions. This currently only supports a couple of primitives and joint types, and parameters are hard-coded.  Very much work in progress.  It may be better to leave it in a branch for now, but I make this PR to make the work public.

Siconos is a general modeling and simulation library for non-smooth dynamical systems, of which mechanical rigid body systems are a subset.  More information on Siconos can be found at http://siconos.gforge.inria.fr/

summary.html:
This adds integration of a Siconos-based Physics engine to Gazebo. Note that it currently depends on the git 'master' branch of Siconos. Once Siconos 4.1.0 is released, I will work on stable and 'master' versions. Siconos is not yet available through Debian/Ubuntu, however a daily PPA is available and a stable Debian package is currently in development.

This currently only supports a couple of primitives and joint types, and parameters are hard-coded. Very much work in progress. It may be better to leave it in a branch for now, but I make this PR to make the work public.

Siconos is a general modeling and simulation library for non-smooth dynamical systems, of which mechanical rigid body systems are a subset. More information on Siconos can be found at http://siconos.gforge.inria.fr/

  • Add physics engine "siconos", with a skeleton PhysicsEngine instance.

    No joints implemented, parameters are hard-coded, many TODO items, but basic bouncing ball works.

  • Add SiconosBoxShape.

  • Add rudimentary "add force" mechanism to SiconosLink.

  • Add a bit of friction to the default NSLaw.

  • Vector conversions for SiconosVector and ignition.

  • Use a SiconosContactor for each shape.

  • Enable the GeneralMechanical solver.

  • Implement SiconosHingeJoint.

  • Implement SiconosSliderJoint.

  • Change gazebo8_siconos_integration to siconos_integration

values.reason: Declining this pull request in order to triage old pull requests.

values.description:
This is only a small change which allows more flexibility in the use of ``PhysicsEngine`` (more specifically the ``ContactManager`` which it provides).

Currently the policy is that contacts are only processed further if there are subscribers to the contacts topic. Method [ContactMangaer::NewContact()](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/commits/2251e3885184c88099722869a34d552198e5c728#Lgazebo/physics/ContactManager.hhF99T102) is used by all the ``PhysicsEngine`` implementations to notify about new found contacts. If an object (not NULL) is returned, the contacts processing continues in the ``PhysicsEngine`` implementations, and ``ContactManager`` will have the full information available. However if there are no subscribers, NewContact() returns NULL, effectively skipping to keep the contact point information.

It is important (for performance reasons) to have a means to skip further processing, and having the subscriber criterion is one way to proclaim interest in more information about the contacts. However it would be great to have another option to proclaim this interest and allow contacts processing, without the need to create a subscriber to the topic.
This PR addresses this by adding a method [ContactManager::SetEnforceContacts(true)](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/commits/2251e3885184c88099722869a34d552198e5c728#Lgazebo/physics/ContactManager.hhT108)  which allows to enforce the contact point handling even if there are no subscribers. By default this behaviour is disabled, so the changes will not have any effects on previous applications which do not explicitly call this function with true.

Example use case: In the physics engine test framework I'm working on at the moment, I use PhysicsEngine directly and have no subscribers or publishers to communicate with the core Gazebo code. In the tests I need to get the contact points information. I would prefer not having to create a fake subscriber just to be able to get this information out of ContactManager interface. Other users may need the same feature.
values.title: Possibility to enforce contact addition in ContactManager even if there are no subscribers

summary.raw:
This is only a small change which allows more flexibility in the use of ``PhysicsEngine`` (more specifically the ``ContactManager`` which it provides).

Currently the policy is that contacts are only processed further if there are subscribers to the contacts topic. Method [ContactMangaer::NewContact()](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/commits/2251e3885184c88099722869a34d552198e5c728#Lgazebo/physics/ContactManager.hhF99T102) is used by all the ``PhysicsEngine`` implementations to notify about new found contacts. If an object (not NULL) is returned, the contacts processing continues in the ``PhysicsEngine`` implementations, and ``ContactManager`` will have the full information available. However if there are no subscribers, NewContact() returns NULL, effectively skipping to keep the contact point information.

It is important (for performance reasons) to have a means to skip further processing, and having the subscriber criterion is one way to proclaim interest in more information about the contacts. However it would be great to have another option to proclaim this interest and allow contacts processing, without the need to create a subscriber to the topic.
This PR addresses this by adding a method [ContactManager::SetEnforceContacts(true)](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/commits/2251e3885184c88099722869a34d552198e5c728#Lgazebo/physics/ContactManager.hhT108)  which allows to enforce the contact point handling even if there are no subscribers. By default this behaviour is disabled, so the changes will not have any effects on previous applications which do not explicitly call this function with true.

Example use case: In the physics engine test framework I'm working on at the moment, I use PhysicsEngine directly and have no subscribers or publishers to communicate with the core Gazebo code. In the tests I need to get the contact points information. I would prefer not having to create a fake subscriber just to be able to get this information out of ContactManager interface. Other users may need the same feature.
summary.html:
This is only a small change which allows more flexibility in the use of PhysicsEngine (more specifically the ContactManager which it provides).

Currently the policy is that contacts are only processed further if there are subscribers to the contacts topic. Method ContactMangaer::NewContact() is used by all the PhysicsEngine implementations to notify about new found contacts. If an object (not NULL) is returned, the contacts processing continues in the PhysicsEngine implementations, and ContactManager will have the full information available. However if there are no subscribers, NewContact() returns NULL, effectively skipping to keep the contact point information.

It is important (for performance reasons) to have a means to skip further processing, and having the subscriber criterion is one way to proclaim interest in more information about the contacts. However it would be great to have another option to proclaim this interest and allow contacts processing, without the need to create a subscriber to the topic. This PR addresses this by adding a method ContactManager::SetEnforceContacts(true) which allows to enforce the contact point handling even if there are no subscribers. By default this behaviour is disabled, so the changes will not have any effects on previous applications which do not explicitly call this function with true.

Example use case: In the physics engine test framework I'm working on at the moment, I use PhysicsEngine directly and have no subscribers or publishers to communicate with the core Gazebo code. In the tests I need to get the contact points information. I would prefer not having to create a fake subscriber just to be able to get this information out of ContactManager interface. Other users may need the same feature.

values.description:
This is tiny. But should be run through the tests on jenkins just in case (my laptop is bad for testing).

Contact points are not processed in Bullet if they are on the surface (exactly 0 distance). When I have spheres rolling on a flat ground, it doesn't display any contact points in gzclient. Adding a ``=`` fixes this.
values.title: BULLET: Contact points on surface should be processed as well

This is tiny. But should be run through the tests on jenkins just in case (my laptop is bad for testing).

Contact points are not processed in Bullet if they are on the surface (exactly 0 distance). When I have spheres rolling on a flat ground, it doesn't display any contact points in gzclient. Adding a ``=`` fixes this.
summary.html:
This is tiny. But should be run through the tests on jenkins just in case (my laptop is bad for testing).

Contact points are not processed in Bullet if they are on the surface (exactly 0 distance). When I have spheres rolling on a flat ground, it doesn't display any contact points in gzclient. Adding a = fixes this.

values.description:
Fixed half of #1564. The CPU RaySensor seeing through close objects is fixed. It's probably easier to review each commit individually.

The parent of the sensor is set to not collide during range measurements. Rays are then cast from the origin of the sensor, and values less than minimum range are set to -inf afterwards.

If the physics engine does not support collision masks, the RaySensor falls back to previous strategy that has issue #1564. This only affects simbody, once #867 is fixed anyeays 

To physics::Collision added

* GetCategoryBits()
* GetCollisionBits()
* SupportsCategoryBits()
* SupportsCollisionBits()


Fixed LaserVisual -inf being displayed as +inf
values.title: Ray sensor 1564 cpu

summary.raw:
Fixed half of #1564. The CPU RaySensor seeing through close objects is fixed. It's probably easier to review each commit individually.

The parent of the sensor is set to not collide during range measurements. Rays are then cast from the origin of the sensor, and values less than minimum range are set to -inf afterwards.

If the physics engine does not support collision masks, the RaySensor falls back to previous strategy that has issue #1564. This only affects simbody, once #867 is fixed anyeays 

To physics::Collision added

* GetCategoryBits()
* GetCollisionBits()
* SupportsCategoryBits()
* SupportsCollisionBits()


Fixed LaserVisual -inf being displayed as +inf
summary.html:
Fixed half of #1564. The CPU RaySensor seeing through close objects is fixed. It's probably easier to review each commit individually.

The parent of the sensor is set to not collide during range measurements. Rays are then cast from the origin of the sensor, and values less than minimum range are set to -inf afterwards.

If the physics engine does not support collision masks, the RaySensor falls back to previous strategy that has issue #1564. This only affects simbody, once #867 is fixed anyeays

To physics::Collision added

  • GetCategoryBits()
  • GetCollisionBits()
  • SupportsCategoryBits()
  • SupportsCollisionBits()

Fixed LaserVisual -inf being displayed as +inf

values.description:
The example gui plugins were failing to compile since it was unable to find qt5. This was fixed by setting the environment variables properly using `$ENV{}` instead of `${}` in cmake.

* Require cmake to find qt5 packages in example gui plugins

* fix environment variables in tests
values.title: Fix examples compilation (#2177)

values.description:
Previously done in pull request #2485. Problem with LOD not behaving as expected should be fixed now. Turn on wireframe to see the resolution of the heightmap mesh changes as camera zooms in and out. It should work with `worlds/heightmap.world`.

Added support to configure LOD  on:

* client side using `gui.ini`, e.g.

        [heightmap]
        lod=3

* server and client side using a visual plugin.

values.description:
By adding an iterator this removes the requirement to know
some implementation details of GpuLaser in order to get
data from it. It removes a couple magic numbers that were
being used in GpuRaySensor when using the data.

* Deprecates float* GpuLaser::LaserData()
* Adds DataIter GpuLaser::LaserDataBegin()
* Adds DataIter GpuLaser::LaserDataEnd()
values.title: Added GpuLaserDataIterator to replace some magic numbers

values.description:
This is another piece out of pull request #2633, but done a little better. It adds a way to query the capabilities of a physics engine.

Capabilities that can be queried are `CATEGORY_BITS` and `COLLIDE_BITS`, which are needed for fixing #1564. All four physics engines default to returning `false` if a capability is unknown.

* Adds `PhysicsEngine::Capability` enum
* Adds `virtual bool PhysicsEngine::Supports(Capability)`
* Adds a simple test checking if Supports() throws
values.title: Added support for querying a physics engine's capabilities

* Adds `virtual bool PhysicsEngine::Supports(Capability)`
* Adds a simple test checking if Supports() throws

values.description:
Add API for setting shadow texture size. Larger shadow texture size generally produces higher quality shadows.

Not part of this PR is a `ShadowPlugin` in `shadow_texture_plugin_7` branch that I created to demonstrate the functionality. If you're interested in trying it out, you can switch to that branch and run:

~~~
gazebo worlds/box_shadow_plugin.world
~~~

Bring up the camera sensor image in Topic Viewer and see that the shadows have reduced in quality (size changed from 1024 to 256).

jenkins:

[xenial-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/64/) - should be ok. The test failures look unrelated

values.description:
Re-enbled saving of ogre terrain tile data to disk in the `~/.gazebo/paging` directory. The benefit is more evident with large heightmaps. The first time a large heightmap is loaded, it'll take longer for gazebo to launch due to the additional step of writing data to disk. Subsequent launches should be faster as ogre would no longer need to generate the tiles again.

[Here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b6uqlr6s3yjvv7/red_dem.zip?dl=0) is a large dem heightmap to test with. From local testing: 

First run:
~~~
[Msg] Heightmap loaded. Process took: 5.39788 seconds
[Msg] Saving heightmap cache data to /home/ian/.gazebo/paging/dem
[Msg] Heightmap cache data saved. Process took: 7.12726 seconds.
~~~

Second run:
~~~
[Msg] Heightmap loaded. Process took: 1.62002 seconds
~~~

jenkins:

[xenial-nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/69/) - ok

[abi](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/243/API_ABI_report/) - ok
values.title: Cache heightmap tile data

values.description:
This adds <collide_bitmask> support to bullet.

There was some code that looked like an attempt to add support that was never completed. This pull request keeps a limitation from this old code: BulletLink adds all collisions on a Link to the same btRigidBody and uses the bitmask of the first collision. I cannot find a way to remove this limitation without breaking ABI.

Future work could remove this limitation by having BulletLink create a btRigidBody for every collision and join them together with fixed constraints. Then every collision could have it's own mask.
values.title: [gazebo7] Added <collide_bitmask> support to bullet

summary.raw:
This adds <collide_bitmask> support to bullet.

There was some code that looked like an attempt to add support that was never completed. This pull request keeps a limitation from this old code: BulletLink adds all collisions on a Link to the same btRigidBody and uses the bitmask of the first collision. I cannot find a way to remove this limitation without breaking ABI.

Future work could remove this limitation by having BulletLink create a btRigidBody for every collision and join them together with fixed constraints. Then every collision could have it's own mask.
summary.html:
This adds <collide_bitmask> support to bullet.

There was some code that looked like an attempt to add support that was never completed. This pull request keeps a limitation from this old code: BulletLink adds all collisions on a Link to the same btRigidBody and uses the bitmask of the first collision. I cannot find a way to remove this limitation without breaking ABI.

Future work could remove this limitation by having BulletLink create a btRigidBody for every collision and join them together with fixed constraints. Then every collision could have it's own mask.

values.description:
The `ModelEditorUndoTest.LinkScaling` and `ModelManipulationTest.Shortcuts` have been failing on OS X, but they pass if you change the order of the tests. There is probably an issue with memory management in a previous test. This doesn't resolve the underlying problem, but it does fix the jenkins result.

* [recent jenkins results](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/21/testReport/)

Resolves issues #2197.

Resolves issues #2197.
summary.html:
The ModelEditorUndoTest.LinkScaling and ModelManipulationTest.Shortcuts have been failing on OS X, but they pass if you change the order of the tests. There is probably an issue with memory management in a previous test. This doesn't resolve the underlying problem, but it does fix the jenkins result.

  • recent jenkins results

Resolves issues #2197.

values.description:
This plugin will be used during the SRC. It wouldn't be convenient to use ignition transport with Gazebo 7, so it uses gazebo transport.

I hope the documentation on the plugin is enough to make its usage clear.
